articles.headline: Corporate Japan Is on Foreign Buying Spree. Toshiba Shows Pitfalls.
articles.snippet: Japanese companies are buying up businesses abroad as the population and spending shrivel at home, but past deals show a costly tendency to overpay.
articles.abstract: Japanese companies are buying up businesses abroad as the population and spending shrivel at home, but past deals show a costly tendency to overpay.
articles.lead_paragraph: TOKYO — Toshiba of Japan had big dreams for global expansion when it bought the American nuclear company Westinghouse 11 years ago. To make them come true, it seemed willing to pay almost any price.

articles.headline: G.O.P. Senators Suggest Changes for Health Care Bill Offered by House
articles.snippet: Speaker Paul D. Ryan cited the Congressional Budget Office’s forecast for a $337 billion cut in the deficit to try to gain the backing of G.O.P. conservatives.
articles.abstract: Speaker Paul D. Ryan cited the Congressional Budget Office’s forecast for a $337 billion cut in the deficit to try to gain the backing of G.O.P. conservatives.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — A day after a harsh judgment by the Congressional Budget Office on the House plan to repeal the Affordable Care Act, nervous Senate Republicans on Tuesday suggested changes to the bill.
articles.byline: By Jennifer Steinhauer and Thomas Kaplan

articles.headline: Prerequisite for Key White House Posts: Loyalty, Not Experience
articles.snippet: Numerous top aides to President Trump don’t bring the typical expertise to their positions. They do bring fidelity to Mr. Trump.
articles.abstract: Numerous top aides to President Trump don’t bring the typical expertise to their positions. They do bring fidelity to Mr. Trump.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Trump’s point man on Israeli-Palestinian negotiations is a longtime Trump Organization lawyer with no government or diplomatic experience. His liaison to African-American leaders is a former reality-TV villain with a penchant for résumé inflation. And his Oval Office gatekeeper is a bullet-headed former New York City cop best known for smacking a protester on the head.
articles.byline: By Sharon LaFraniere, Nicholas Confessore and Jesse Drucker

articles.headline: Neil Gorsuch Has Web of Ties to Secretive Billionaire
articles.snippet: Mr. Gorsuch, President Trump’s Supreme Court pick, represented the mogul Philip F. Anschutz as an outside counsel and has links to other executives at his companies.
articles.abstract: Mr. Gorsuch, President Trump’s Supreme Court pick, represented the mogul Philip F. Anschutz as an outside counsel and has links to other executives at his companies.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The publicity-shy billionaire Philip F. Anschutz inherited an oil and gas firm and built it into an empire that has sprawled into telecommunications, railroads, real estate, resorts, sports teams, stadiums, movies and conservative publications like The Weekly Standard and The Washington Examiner.
articles.byline: By Charlie Savage and Julie Turkewitz

articles.headline: Monsanto Weed Killer Roundup Faces New Doubts on Safety in Unsealed Documents
articles.snippet: A lawsuit contends that the main ingredient in Roundup, the world’s most widely used weed killer, can cause cancer.
articles.abstract: A lawsuit contends that the main ingredient in Roundup, the world’s most widely used weed killer, can cause cancer.
articles.lead_paragraph: The reputation of Roundup, whose active ingredient is the world’s most widely used weed killer, took a hit on Tuesday when a federal court unsealed documents raising questions about its safety and the research practices of its manufacturer, the chemical giant Monsanto.

articles.headline: Trump Wrote Off $100 Million in Losses in 2005, Leaked Forms Show
articles.snippet: The MSNBC host Rachel Maddow disclosed information from President Trump’s 2005 tax return on Tuesday night.
articles.abstract: The MSNBC host Rachel Maddow disclosed information from President Trump’s 2005 tax return on Tuesday night.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Trump wrote off more than $100 million in business losses to reduce his federal taxes in 2005, according to forms made public on Tuesday night: a rare glimpse at documents that he had refused to disclose since becoming a candidate for the nation’s highest office.
articles.byline: By Peter Baker and Jesse Drucker

articles.headline: Fed Raises Interest Rates for Third Time Since Financial Crisis
articles.snippet: The move will increase the upward pressure on interest rates that consumers pay, but the immediate effect is likely to be modest.
articles.abstract: The move will increase the upward pressure on interest rates that consumers pay, but the immediate effect is likely to be modest.
articles.lead_paragraph: The Federal Reserve, which raised its benchmark rate on Wednesday for the second time in three months, this time to a range between 0.75 percent and 1 percent, is finally moving toward the end of its nine-year-old economic stimulus campaign, which began in the depths of the financial crisis.

articles.headline: How the Internet Is Saving Culture, Not Killing It
articles.snippet: There has been huge growth in digital subscription services, and they are revolutionizing every cultural industry.
articles.abstract: There has been huge growth in digital subscription services, and they are revolutionizing every cultural industry.
articles.lead_paragraph: One secret to longevity as a pundit is to issue predictions that can’t be easily checked. So here’s one for the time capsule: Two hundred years from now, give or take, the robot-people of Earth will look back on the early years of the 21st century as the beginning of a remarkable renaissance in art and culture.

articles.headline: Russian Agents Were Behind Yahoo Hack, U.S. Says
articles.snippet: Four men, including two Russian intelligence agents, were charged for their roles in the theft of 500 million Yahoo accounts in 2014.
articles.abstract: Four men, including two Russian intelligence agents, were charged for their roles in the theft of 500 million Yahoo accounts in 2014.
articles.lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — The Justice Department charged two Russian intelligence officers on Wednesday with directing a sweeping criminal conspiracy that stole data on 500 million Yahoo accounts in 2014, deepening the rift between American and Russian authorities on cybersecurity.
articles.byline: By Vindu Goel and Eric Lichtblau
